scene.name: start
scene.line: `(CATE gently rolls a fallen branch and plucks something white from the underside. She holds it up for EZRA to examine.)`
`Pleurocybella porrigens`. The common name is "angel wings." Isn't that pleasant? They have a delicate, springy texture, and they're tasty, like sweet moss. Would you like a bite?
scene.option: Sweet moss doesn't sound very tasty to me ...

scene.name: eat-angel-wing
scene.line: `(EZRA takes a small bite and ruminates)`
What do you think?
scene.option: Is it supposed to be spicy?
I think I got a bug.

scene.name: angel-wing-spicy
scene.line: Um, no ... go ahead and spit that out, it's OK.

scene.name: angel-wing-bug
scene.line: Oh, lucky you.
I'm kidding, you can spit it out if you want.

scene.name: angel-wing-moss
scene.line: Personally, I like to be able to tell where my food came from, by flavor alone. I like to taste my surroundings, I mean. It keeps me connected to the ... the whole thing.

scene.name: mushroom-hunting-intro
scene.line: She lit a second cigarette with the embers of the first one. She trembled, sweating a little under a heavy coat. It was warmer near the doors, but she was following directions: "no smoking within 25 feet of hospital entrance."
So she stood by a hot dog cart parked at the edge of the sidewalk.
My mushroom-hunting mentor told me, "it's useless to pretend to know mushrooms; they escape your erudition; the more you know them, the less sure you feel about identifying them."
`(She taps the cover of the small red book she's carrying.)` That's why I always bring my favorite guidebook.
`(CATE points to a small mushroom growing in the dirt.)`

Oh, here's an important one to recognize, though. Look, see the sort of greenish pallor of the cap? `Amanita phalloides`. That's Greek: "amanita" means mushroom, and "phalloides" means, um ... never mind.

scene.name: amanita-edible
scene.line: Only once! It's deadly poisonous.

scene.name: amanita-smell
scene.line: Yeah. Sort of nauseating, though, right? Sickly-sweet.

scene.name: amanita-deadly
scene.line: "Death Cap," that's the common name. It's killed a lot of people, this little mushroom — including a few Roman emperors. It's a revolutionary! Ha ha.
Even the Buddha died from eating a mushroom, when he was very old. That's just what they do: clear away old things, make room for new things.
Pretty important, right? I've always thought they deserved a little more respect.
Would you like to help me look for a few more? I have a sort of shopping list.
Great. Look for ... actually, just grab any mushrooms that catch your eye and throw them in this bag. Let me know when you're done and we'll see what you've got!

scene.name: have-fun
scene.line: "Have fun!" That's the second rule of mushroom hunting. The first rule is "ask Cate before eating anything," OK?

scene.name: cate-explores
scene.option: `(CATE digs in a bare patch of dirt.)`

scene.name: grass
scene.line: `(She parts the grass with her garden knife, studiously combing the ground.)`
`(There are no mushrooms in the grass.)`

scene.name: dirt
scene.line: `(It's a bit muddy from flooding or the general dampness of the caves. She finds two promising specimens: a spotted brown cap, and a dense bundle of dark ridges.)`
scene.option: `(CATE inspects the dense bundle of dark ridges.)`

scene.name: bitter-hedgehog
scene.line: `(The bottom of the cap is covered in tiny, tooth-like protrusions.)`
scene.option: `(CATE plucks the mushroom from the dirt and puts it in her bag.)`

scene.name: false-morel
scene.line: `(Dark brown ridges and folds cover the surface of the mushroom. It has a pleasant, almost fruity smell.)`
scene.option: `(CATE plucks the mushroom from the dirt and puts it in her bag.)`

scene.name: tree-roots
scene.line: `(She spots a couple of intriguing growths along the roots of the tree: a speckled white ball, and a cluster of softly glowing, amber caps.)`

scene.name: shoelace
scene.line: `(The mushrooms are slick, sticky to the touch, like they're covered in smoldering honey.)`
scene.option: `(Cate cuts the bundle of mushrooms from the tree roots and puts them in her bag.)`

scene.name: bat-egg
scene.line: `(About the size of an egg, the mushroom has no visible stem. It seems to be attached to the tree root by a sticky black substance leaking from a ring of tiny pores.)`
scene.option: `(Cate gently pries the mushroom off the tree root and puts it in her bag.)`

scene.name: ezra-explores
scene.option: `(EZRA pokes around the base of a cypress tree.)`
`(EZRA checks out a plastic bag washed up on the island.)`

scene.name: rotting-stump
scene.line: `(The stump is ringed with overlapping shelves of mushrooms striped brown-blue-gray-white. A caterpillar crawls along one of them.)`
He didn't have any friends nearby; none of their new neighbors seemed to have children his age. So he played alone in the woods, alone, except for the deer.

scene.name: turkey-tail
scene.line: `(It smells spicy, sweet, mild; like how EZRA had expected his father's tobacco to taste, when he hastily chewed and swallowed a noxious fistful, and spent the afternoon retching in secret.)`
He heard someone calling his name; probably his mother, but her voice didn't sound right through the trees. He kept going.
scene.option: `(EZRA tears off a piece of the mushroom and puts it in his bag.)`

scene.name: cordyceps
scene.line: `(The caterpillar shuffles listlessly across the mushroom. It seems to be dragging several of its legs. An odd, brown-black thread protrudes about two inches out of its head.)`
He saw strange lights in the trees, flickering purple. He kept going.
scene.option: `(EZRA carefully picks up the caterpillar and puts it in his bag.)`

scene.name: base-of-tree
scene.line: `(A brownish clump of mushrooms feathers out from the base of the cypress tree. A few feet above, several pale blue puffs cling to the trunk.)`

The woods were full of deer. His dad said the deer liked best to live on the edges of forests. Recent development in the area had created a lot of fresh edges, so they massed here and sometimes ran into the road.
scene.option: `(EZRA crouches to get a closer look at the brownish clump.)`

scene.name: sheeps-head
scene.line: `(The mushrooms look dried out and brittle, almost like tree bark.)`
He heard strange, gruff voices back in the direction of the house, and something that sounded like a choked sob or a sharp rebuke. He kept going.
scene.option: `(EZRA tears off a piece of the mushroom and puts it in his bag.)`

scene.name: puffball
scene.line: `(He prods one of the pale orbs with a stick, and it cracks open a little, releasing a fine dust into the air.)`
He felt like the world outside the woods had somehow slipped away while he was gone, and now there was nothing but the woods. He kept going.
scene.option: `(EZRA carefully removes a puffball, and puts it in his bag.)`

scene.name: plastic-bag
scene.line: `(The bag is ragged and waterlogged. He nudges it with a stick, coiling up a plastic thread and spreading it out on the beach.)`

He'd taken a knife from the kitchen, selected for its long, serrated edge. Meant for slicing bread, its teeth had reminded him of a saw blade. He was determined to collect some firewood to heat the house.
`(There are no mushrooms in the bag.)`

scene.name: done-hunting
scene.line: Didn't find anything? That's OK.
Oh, you got one? Let's see it.
Wow, that looks like quite a haul! Let's see what you've got.
`(EZRA hands CATE the striped mushroom he took from the tree stump.)`
Oh, great. This is called a "turkey tail." Delicious, and good for the immune system.
`(EZRA hands CATE the caterpillar he found on the tree stump.)`

Is this a caterpillar? Oh, I see ... Did you get a look at this black thread coming out of his head? That's actually a fungus. It grows in the caterpillar, eats it from the inside out, even changes its behavior a bit!
They kill for these in Tibet. I don't have much use for them in my line of work, though.
`(EZRA hands CATE the brittle, brownish mushroom he took from the base of the cypress tree.)`

Aha! Brown gold. Most people call these "sheep's head," but in alternative medicine circles it's better known by its Japanese name: "maitake," the dancing mushroom. Apt, because you do a happy little dance when you find one.
It fights cancer, supports the immune system, regulates blood sugar, and tastes like eggplant. This one's a bit old and tough, but it's nothing that can't be solved with a lot of butter.
Good find, Ezra!
`(EZRA hands CATE the blue puffball he took from the cypress tree.)`

A blue puffball ... interesting. I don't think I've seen this `exact` species before. This one's too old to be of any use, anyway. Puffballs get all dried out like this as they age, until they're so delicate that it only takes the slightest agitation —
`(CATE gently shakes the puffball. It bursts into a cloud of spores.)`
— and the wind does the rest. See, it's `weakness` as a survival strategy. A kind of radical, transformative weakness.

I didn't find anything either. You never know when or how they'll appear, with mushrooms. There are a few species that can be cultivated, but mostly the conditions that make them grow are just too complicated and obscure to reproduce.
They're one of the only truly `wild` things left in this world. I mean, even the weather is more or less under the influence of human industry at this point, right?
You've got me beat; I didn't find a thing.
I just found this one:
Here's my haul:
`(CATE takes the spotted brown cap out of her bag.)`
OK, this one is called "Bitter Hedgehog," and it's on my list. It's great for nausea, which is basically the number one complaint of the pregnant women I treat.
It tastes kind of like black pepper ... It's `OK`. I let it dry out so it's really tough, and they just chew on it like bubble gum.
`(CATE takes the dense bundle of dark ridges out of her bag.)`
This one I can't really use, but I picked it just to show it to you. It looks a lot like a very popular eating mushroom around these parts, called a "morel." But it's not a morel.
`(CATE slices the mushroom in half, lengthwise. It's full of white fiber, the consistency of cotton.)`
This is the easiest way to tell them apart. The real morel is empty. `This` one, the "false morel," is actually kind of poisonous!
I forget what its effects are, exactly ... Here, let's check the `Vermeulen` book.
`(CATE flips through the pages of her guidebook.)`
OK, here it is: `(Reading.)` "... Symptoms include wanting to fight; demanding answers; dryness of eyes, nose, and lips; restless sleep ..."
"... Dreams of flood, of rolling stones, accidents, people transforming into owls, vampires, rockets, and traveling to stars ..."
Huh. That doesn't sound so bad, actually ...
`(CATE puts the mushroom back into her bag.)`
`(CATE takes the bundle of amber caps from her bag.)`
These ones are really cool. See how they kind of glow a little?
It's not enough to find your way in the dark or anything, but still pretty amazing.
Anyway, I make a tea out of them; pretty good for headaches.
`(CATE puts the mushrooms back into her bag.)`
`(CATE takes the speckled white ball out of her bag.)`
These are called "bat eggs." See this gooey black stuff leaking out the side here? I guess somebody somewhere once thought this stuff looked like egg yolk, and it's black, like a bat ...
I mean — I'm kind of speculating. I don't `really` know why they're called "bat eggs."
They're not good for anything, really, and they'll give you bad stomach ache if you try to eat them. I just wanted to show it to you.
`(CATE tosses the "bat egg" into the water.)`

He tripped on a protruding root and lay for a while in the mud, examining the pale upper branches of a sycamore tree, listening to the soft rumble of a faraway thunderstorm, then louder, closer, and his hair stood on end, and there was the bird.
So ...
scene.option: What do your parents do? For work, I mean.
You have a brother out there somewhere?

scene.name: ezra-parents
scene.line: My dad used to sell windows. People were building a lot of new houses, and they needed a lot of windows, but then they stopped building houses.

My mom worked at a bakery and a bar. Sometimes she would see the same people in the morning and the evening. The bakery closed, and she doesn't work at the bar anymore, but she still goes there a lot to see her friends.

scene.name: ezra-brother
scene.line: Julian. He's going to come find me in the morning, after the work is done.
Yep, we work pretty hard. We used to spend part of each night looking for my folks, but now we pretty much just work ... but maybe that'll change now. I have some new friends.

scene.name: ezra-asks-about-family
scene.line: Do you have a family?
scene.option: I almost had a baby once.
I left home when I was very young. Not much older than you, actually.

scene.name: miscarriage
scene.option: I learned a lot about difficult pregnancies, at least. So now I can help other women.
I got very sick, and the only thing that helped me was a funny-looking mushroom called "collared earthstar."

scene.name: runaway
scene.option: I bounced around jobs and shelters, and finally found my way down to the Echo River. Never looked back.
Years later my mother got sick and I tried to visit her, but it was too late. She was all spaced out on fevers and morphine.

scene.name: memorial-wait
scene.line: I've basically been on my own since then ... Well, that's not really true. Just about everyone who sets foot aboard `The Mucky Mammoth` feels like family to me now. I guess if `nobody`'s family, then `everybody`'s family. Ha ha.

scene.name: memorial
scene.line: Months later, she came across a book on homeopathic medicine in a used bookstore, and bought it. She thought it was mostly bullshit, but found the author's notes on the unpredictability of mushrooms immediately compelling. Spiritual, even.

She started collecting mushrooms on hikes; never eating them, just collecting, identifying, and discarding. Eventually, she connected with the Lexington Mycological Society, and began to study in earnest the medicinal uses of fungi.
scene.option: These are the only trees in this whole cave. Who planted them here?
What's this island for? It looks like someone made it on purpose.

scene.name: memorial-trees
scene.line: Right, not many trees down here in the dark ...
I know these are ... some kind of cypress. And they were definitely planted here deliberately, uh ... by someone who ...

scene.name: memorial-island
scene.line: Oh, right, it's kind of a nice, simple shape. Pleasantly minimal island geometry.
I'm sure it `could` be natural, though. I mean, I don't know if the island itself is man-made or not, but ...

scene.name: memorial-background
scene.line: I guess I don't know much about this place, really. It's supposed to be some kind of memorial? To something?
Will would know more.
Sorry, it's a mystery.
It's a mystery!
I'll search for clues.

scene.name: cypress-tree
scene.line: `(The tree smells spicy, oily.)`

scene.name: edge-of-water
scene.line: `(EZRA steps on a plastic bottle. A wooden post projects from the sand nearby.)`

scene.name: large-rock
scene.line: `(The monument is covered with lichen and painted text.)`

scene.name: examine-bark-graffiti
scene.line: `(A message is carved in the bark.)`
OZY

scene.name: examine-trimmed-branches
scene.line: `(Some of the branches have been trimmed recently.)`

scene.name: examine-mooring-post
scene.line: `(A groove is worn near the top of the post.)`

scene.name: examine-plastic-bottle
scene.line: `(There's a scrap of paper inside the bottle. EZRA takes it out and reads it.)`
EGGS FLOUR CHARDONNAY LAXATIVES PAPER TOWELS SCRATCH TICKET

scene.name: examine-rock-graffiti
scene.line: X+O 4EVA

scene.name: examine-lichen
scene.line: `(Colorful lichen coats the surface of the monument, mixing with painted graffiti, in some places indistinguishably.)`

scene.name: ezra-returns-with-evidence
scene.line: She put out her cigarette, said goodbye to the hot dog vendor, and spent the rest of the afternoon listening to doctors, and trying to understand the world as they did: as a list of discrete injuries to be mended.
Alright, what have you got?
That stone face monument has "x+o 4eva" painted on it.
Interesting. What do you think that means? "Hug and kiss forever?"
Or they could be initials. "Xavier and Olivia forever."
"Xerxes and Oliver?"
There's some weird, colorful moss growing on the stone face monument.
Ah, that's called "lichen." It's actually part fungus. It's sort of a weird hybrid.
Not really my area of expertise, but some of it has useful medicinal properties. And some of it is poison. The usual. Ha ha.
It's beautiful, though, isn't it?
What do you think that monument is for?
I'm not sure anyone remembers.
That's my new favorite rock.
Wow, even better than "Dinosaur Rock?"
... I think so.
Somebody carved "OZY" in that tree over there.
Oh, huh. What do you think that means?
It's part of somebody's name. Or it's short for something.
"Observe |Zero| Yaks."
"Old Zebra Yard."
"Ornery Zoologist Yacht."
I don't know what that means.
Yeah, it was a stretch.
The branches on the tree are trimmed.
Oh, good observation! So I guess somebody's still taking care of this place. Or just practicing their tree-trimming somewhere out of the way ...
There's a pole in the ground over there; it's all scratched up.
Oh, yeah. I bet people tie their boats there.
Maybe somebody who takes care of the trees.
Could be. Or other travelers and mushroom hunters, like us.
I found this message in a bottle.
Looks like somebody's grocery list.
Well, Ezra, I can't say I know what that all adds up to ... Like I said, I wish Will were here. He'd have some local history for us. We can ask him, back on the boat.

scene.name: iron-pariah-appears
scene.line: `(CATE and EZRA look up at an old battleship drifting by.)`
Oh, there it is. `The Iron Pariah`. Don't worry, it's just passing by.
scene.option: What do you think of it?
I don't know much about it first-hand, but I've heard things ...

scene.name: iron-pariah-question-origin
scene.line: Yeah, it's a mystery. I don't think it was `built` here, so it must have come from somewhere ...
There are a lot of ways to get here, though. All these caves are connected, and the same for rivers.
It's hard to know where `anything` down here really comes from.

scene.name: iron-pariah-question-been-aboard
scene.line: Oh, no. I've never even been close. I have to admit I'm a `little` curious, but ...
Well, sometimes places get an aura of the forbidden about them, and it just seems best to stay away.
Plus: it would ruin the mystery!

scene.name: iron-pariah-question-ghosts
scene.line: Oh, I don't know, probably ...
I mean — no, definitely not. You don't believe in ghosts, do you?
No ...
I've never met a young kid who `really` believed in ghosts. Lots of older people do, though. I wonder why that is.

scene.name: iron-pariah-rumors
scene.option: I've heard it was in the Civil War.
Supposedly there's nobody even aboard. No people, I mean.
Someone told me she got close to it by accident, and heard a strange wailing sound.

scene.name: iron-pariah-rumor-civil-war
scene.line: I guess they had boats full of soldiers and supplies going up and down the Ohio River. And they fought on the river, like, boat-to-boat, with cannons or something, I guess. Machine guns?
I'm no military historian, as you can probably tell. Ha ha.
Anyway, I guess this one just got lost, and somehow ended up all the way down here. Maybe it slipped into a cave up north; they're all connected, underground.
There's another version of the story where it didn't get lost — it was full of deserters. They came down here to hide. Maybe that's why it's a "Pariah."

scene.name: iron-pariah-rumor-no-people
scene.line: I mean, there must be `something` on there. Life is everywhere. Rats, insects, some kind of hardy mold ...
Part of it could be flooded, and host to some of the eyeless fish that live in the Echo.
Hey, maybe there are some mushrooms growing in there! Slowly consuming military rations from over a hundred years ago ...

scene.name: iron-pariah-rumor-wailing-sound
scene.line: She was a passenger on the `Mammoth`. She said she'd been out fishing on a rowboat, and got swept up by a current near the Cluttered Place.
Before she knew it, `The Iron Pariah` was upon her — unimaginably massive, up close, but eerily silent.
The only sounds, she said, were the lapping of the lake water against its iron hull, and a faint sort of ... Well, she said a "chorus of `mews`."
I'll be damned if I know what that sounds like! Ha ha. I've never gotten close enough to the ship myself ...

scene.name: iron-pariah-done
scene.line: Ezra's parents shook him awake. They seemed alarmed, but not immediately concerned. They led him back to the house, past the house, into the car.
More mysteries. They do pile up, over time, as people forget the details.
Dad said they were going to stay at the bus station for a while, the one with the little arcade, with the car game he liked.
Thanks for taking me mushroom picking.
Dad watched him closely in the rear-view mirror, expecting Ezra to be excited, or confused, or scared, but he didn't feel anything. He hardly seemed to hear.
Mushroom `hunting`. You can "pick" apples, because they're right out there in the open. Mushrooms hide. You have to hunt for them.
In fact, he felt like he was observing the family car from a distance, from far above, from the clouds.

fragments.fragment: The hot dog vendor tried to strike up a conversation with some immediately-too-personal questions.
She decided to give him the benefit of the doubt; maybe he considered it part of his job, she thought, to offer his customers some kind of counsel.
Maybe it was to salve his guilty conscience, for selling junk food outside a hospital.

Had she ever tried any "alternative" medicines? Acupuncture? Homeopathy? Ayurveda? Magical thinking? She said she'd never heard of any of those things. He fished a stray hot dog out of the pickle jar.

Was she at the hospital because of `that`? He meant the cigarette. Was she visiting family? Was she vegetarian? That last one was all business; he had some veggie dogs in a separate tray at the bottom of the cart.

He didn't like to play in the house. It was always too cold. It seemed to store up the cold at night, then slowly discharge it into his bones during the day, while the sun bounced feebly off the windows.
But he liked to play in the woods behind the house.
